When I know what God says, it enables me to boldly say, the Lord is my helper, I shall not fear what man shall do unto me. That was free tonight, amen? Deuteronomy chapter number 11, and we'll be looking here at the first 17 verses of Deuteronomy 11. Of course, last week, as you know, we started a mini-series that I entitled, The Danger of Deception. I am thoroughly convinced that we are currently living in an age of deception. I believe that as we look around our world, that it is not too difficult for any of us to recognize that we are living in an age of deception. In fact, as we study the Word of God, we find that our God has graciously warned us about the reality of deception. He told us that it was going to be the case. Not only did He warn us about the deception that we would face, but I am very thankful that He has given us the truth of His Word, He has provided us with the remedy for deception. What a blessing to know and to have the Word of God and to know the truth. What a blessing. We will recall that as we began our series last Wednesday evening, that I mentioned to you, and it is worth pointing out again this evening, that the tool of deception has been in the adversary's toolbox since the Garden. We understand that it is a tool that he regularly uses, the tool of deception. It's in his toolbox and he uses it often, and we find that no doubt, even in the age in which we're living, we are facing great deception. If you're taking notes this evening, the title for the message is from verse number 16. I'll read that verse. For sake of time, I won't read all 17 verses. We'll read them as we go through. But in verse number 16, the Bible says this, Take heed to yourselves, that your heart be not deceived. And you turn aside and serve other gods and worship them. So the title for the message this evening, that your heart be not deceived. That your heart be not deceived. Notice in these first four verses, we find this reminder again of the mighty acts of God and what He did. The eyes of the Lord thy God are always upon it from the beginning of the year even unto the end of the year. And it shall come to pass, and then notice this word, if.
